TEXT.citation: Early, R. J., & Whitehorn, J. (2003). One hundred Paiwan texts. Pacific Linguistics, Research School of Pacific and Asian Studies, The Australian National University.
TEXT.BibTeX_citation: @book{100paiwantexts, author = {Robert Early and John Whitehorn}, title = {One Hundred Paiwan Texts}, year = {2003}, publisher = {Pacific Linguistics, Research School of Pacific and Asian Studies, The Australian National University}}
TEXT.source: told by Giłgiław of Vałulu village

S.FORM: aitsu a qam tjara kemłang itjen a mapułat, aitsu a qam matsaqu aravats a kemali tua qipu, saka pazangal aravats a djameqen.
aico a qam tjara kemljang itjen a mapoljat, aico a qam macaqo aravac a kemali toa qipo, saka pazangal aravac a djameqen.
S.TRANSL: We all know about pangolins; they are very good at digging in the earth, and very hard to catch.

S.FORM: nu inika sitjara kiqam a tsautsau, inika djemamedjameq a paqeteleng.
no inika sitjara kiqam a caocao, inika djemamedjameq a paqeteleng.
S.TRANSL: People can’t catch them any old how without being specialists at catching them.

S.FORM: aitsu a qam tja kełangen a mapułat tu rusiaqan; kana manu, sinipasan qam sun, ayaya itjen tua rusiaqan.
aico a qam tja keljangen a mapoljat to rosiaqan; kana mano, sinipasan qam son, ayaya itjen toa rosiaqan.
S.TRANSL: We all know they are very shy. That’s why we say to a shy person: you’ve become a pangolin.

S.FORM: aitsu a qam sasiq a kakanen.
aico a qam sasiq a kakanen.
saka nu patsun tua sasiq maligił aravats.
saka no pacon toa sasiq maligilj aravac.
S.TRANSL: When they see ants they are very clever;

S.FORM: kirimu a kembung timadju, sa tselaki aza qaułivan nimadju, saka mimatsayan.
kirimo a kembong timadjo, sa celaki aza qaoljivan nimadjo, saka mimacayan.
S.TRANSL: they quickly lie down and open their scales and pretend to be dead.

S.FORM: qau nu tevuta azua mareka sasiq a sema taladj tazua mareka qaułivan, tsaqevan anga nimadju tazua qaułivan nimadju; sa vaikan anga a sema tua załum a tsemlak ta qaułivan nimadju.
qao no tevota azoa mareka sasiq a sema taladj tazoa mareka qaoljivan, caqevan anga nimadjo tazoa qaoljivan nimadjo; sa vaikan anga a sema toa zaljom a cemlak ta qaoljivan nimadjo.
S.TRANSL: When the ants come and get inside the scales, they close the scales, go to water, and there open the scales.

S.FORM: nu setjavaw anga azua mareka sasiq, gałuin anga nimadju a keman, aya.
no setjavaw anga azoa mareka sasiq, galjoin anga nimadjo a keman, aya.
S.TRANSL: When the ants float to the surface, they eat them at their leisure.

S.FORM: aitsu a vutjuł nusa qam sanguaq aravats, aya.
aico a votjolj nosa qam sangoaq aravac, aya.
S.TRANSL: Pangolin meat is said to be very tasty;

S.FORM: łakua anema tja kełang nu ika tjen a nakilingaw anga keman, saka kemłang itjen tu namakuda a pasa sanguaq?
ljakoa anema tja keljang no ika tjen a nakilingaw anga keman, saka kemljang itjen to namakoda a pasa sangoaq?
S.TRANSL: but how can we know if we haven’t had the experience of eating it and finding out how tasty it is?

S.FORM: a ti nakeman anga mana ki kemłang.
a ti nakeman anga mana ki kemljang.
S.TRANSL: Those who have eaten it know.
